Zoloft (sertraline):It's a mystery to me why anyone would be afraid to take antidepressants. Well actually no, it's not a mystery. I'm sure it's because of all the sensationalism in the media. It's a good example of what a grave disservice the media can do the public. Mental health medicine is no different from other medicines. This one treats depression. That's why it's called an                  "anti" "depressant". What's less well known is that antidepressants usually treat anxiety as well, including panic attacks. Actually, most antidepressants are some of the safest medicines on the market. Zoloft saved my life. It made a dark gloomy depression just disappear. I felt like a huge burden had been lifted off my shoulders.

Out of the blue was having palpitations, chest and muscle tightness, trembling, no appetite and constant anxiety and panic. Preoccupation with breathing and hyper aware of everything along with sleep disturbances. Became agoraphobic. The first 2-3 weeks I started getting my appetite back and the trembling stopped - I had a hard time getting on it due to extreme nausea and dry heaving and continued anxiety/panic. Thank God I stuck with it after going from 25mg to a minimum therapeutic dose of 50mg- a full 12 weeks later I can eat and sleep and function. Went back to work and can drive again. Focus to read and do a puzzle and reason much better. Still have occasional off days but nothing compared to pre sertraline. I feel it was the best decision I made to continue even when it seemed I was STUCK in Panic/OCD/Anxiety mode. Thank God for my family and friends and Sertraline. Back to work now and able to enjoy my life much more. It’s not a magic wand but it was a life saver for me.

Zoloft (sertraline):I have had panic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, OCD, and depression. I have struggled with anxiety since I was a child. I have been in therapy since I was young, have done CBT and seen my therapist regularly. I have done all of the things that I was supposed to do. Exercise, healthy eating, sunlight, sleep, etc... I developed an intense fear of not sleeping. Literally it consumed all of me. I was insanely depressed because I was mentally exhausted from the anxiety and obsession I developed about sleep. I was able to get through it without medication but it took time and it was very hard. It happened again out of nowhere, nothing triggered me.  That's when I realized I needed medication as I clearly have some time of imbalance in my brain and this isn't my fault nor something I can control. I have been taking 50 mg of Zoloft for 5 weeks now and have improved drastically. I literally have stopped caring about the sleep. Do not give up. Do not let the negative reviews deter you.

Zoloft (sertraline):Simply put, this medication saved my life and allowed me to return to my normal self. I was so hesitant about going on medication for my anxiety but I’m so happy I did. The beginning stages as you are getting used to the medication are rough i won’t lie. But once you get past those 2-3 weeks it’s like a breath of fresh air. I was having panic attacks every day all day long, now I can function normally again and love the life I live :)

After 6 months of constant panic attacks due to PTSD, I turned to my last resort, sertraline. I was prescribed these tablets after a horrendous Christmas eve and the list of side effects left me crying. Terrified of the increased anxiety I would face within the first weeks of taking them. My first two nights on these tablets were HORRIFIC! Throwing up, racing heart rate, severe dizziness (almost a drunk  feeling), intense flashbacks. This is normal! I had 4 weeks of mild side effects after two horrific nights … 4 weeks of feeling lightheaded, extreme tiredness and hot flushes. I am on my 7th week of the tablets and all my side effects have gone and I feel AMAZING! I cannot remember the last time I had a panic attack ! After about 6 months we added welbutrin to counteract the procrastination that Zoloft caused. During the period of having the side effects I went back to the Doctor several times and following helped:1) Valium to help ease the initial increase in anxiety2) First Valium to help overcome the insomnia, but did not help, so put on trazodone.3) Going to the gym and having a good 30 minute intense aerobic exercise session (had to take valium first, so anxiety went down and I had motivation to go)Zoloft comes with side effects, if you get them, go back to your Doctor and get meds to ease the side effects. Don't continue to suffer. I came off Zoloft and recently started it again. Made sure I got prescription for Trazadone and Valium. Week 3 and side effects have been well managed

The only continuing side effect that I seem to have is a deep afternoon tiredness, to the point that I have to take a nap nearly every day now.  I still have some depression, and some days I can get pretty dour. My doctor prescribed Wellbutrin to me today. I'll be combining it with my Zoloft to try to offset some of the fatigue and help with the doldrums. If not for the tiredness, I would give zoloft 10 out of 10. It eliminated my anxiety.

I started having migraines almost immediately, memory loss, scattered thoughts, extremely dry eyes and nightly teeth clenching so bad I had to start wearing a night guard. I actually spent 2 years looking for other reasons with multiple doctors for these ailments but in the end they were all caused by the Zoloft. I finally quit taking it and one by one all these ailments disappeared. I think this is a good drug, it did what it was supposed to do and might work wonders for others, definitely give it a try But if you start having issues like me, don’t suffer for years like I did. Zoloft (sertraline):This past year, I would get panic attacks that would lead to anxiety. The sensations and feelings  would last a day or two, and would go away (happened three different times). I have zero side effects from the meds and every time I increased the dose I had a couple symptoms but no where near like how they were in the beginning. I combined it with CBT and it’s a life changing, I’m successful, confident, and laughing again.
